channel.title: zacblanco.github.io
channel.description: A simple tech blog to keepp you updated on my projects and for interesting tips tricks and hacks.

item.title: Blog transfer
item.description:
Since I'm pretty new to blogging I haven't found the platform yet that I like best. I decided blogger was a little too plain and wordpress had some better layouts but didn't give me enough control, so I've decided to move to jekyll hosting using github pages.

I won't be posting here any longer. Please direct all traffic to zacblanco.github.io.

EDIT:

I just want to add my previous post about an updated site-- well. Now that I'm using Jekyll I won't be able to keep that as the landing page. You can still find it and view-source zacblanco.github.io/s-old/index.html

item.title: Updated Site
item.description:
So I just wanted to let you guys know that I've updated my GitHub pages site. Because I like learning and building things form scratch to learn how everything is put together I built my site from the ground up and learned a few things along the way.

I was inspired to do this redesign after I came across flexbox. A CSS display property that I had not previously known of. It makes a lot of resizing and overall site layout much easier. I was inspired to rebuild my site using this.

The great thing is that flexbox is easy. It just works. and It's trivial to center things in your screen and resize the browser causing them to flow onto other line. It really is a great tool. The one caveat is that it doesn't have great browser support.

I've currently tested on the most updated versions of the major browsers (IE, Chrome, Firefox, Safari) and so far Chrome and Firefox render the page properly. Unfortunately however, Safari definitely does not render the page properly. Most older browsers don't Although I'm not too worried about this. Even with improper display the page is still navigable. IE11 surprisingly does. Even with limited support for this display I think people should start adopting it in their designs so we can force more people to upgrade their browsers, so that everyone can anjoy a modern browsing experience.

Over the next few days I'll do my best to post some simple tutorials using flexbox and some of the new CSS3 tricks I've learned over the weekend while I made my site.

In the meantime you should check out flexboxin5 it helped me figure out what I was doing and what to include in my CSS to fix the layouts. It's a great tutorial

Don't forget to check out the new design!

zacblanco.github.io

Zac

item.title: Internship
item.description:
Just thought it would be fun to share here. As of today I am confirmed to be working as an intern this summer with Hortonworks; a major corporate contributor to the open-source Hadoop platform.

I still have a lot to learn as a ECE/Comp. Sci student, but I'm sure this internship will prepare me for the future. I know that I'll be surrounded by some of the best minds in the industry this summer and I really hope to learn as much as I can from my future colleagues.

In light of this I thought it would be fun to make a new desktop background. I took a large image of the Hortonworks logo, the image editor GIMP and a little magic to pull this together:


Feel free to copy and redistribute this too!

Cheers to a (hopefully) fantastic opportunity.

item.title: Projects and More Interesting Updates
item.description:
So I've been pretty busy these last two weeks with schoolwork and other matters so I haven't had much time to update anything here.

I did want to let you know that I started working on a Java library use and to implement statistics functions that I think would be useful to analyze large datasets.

For now I'm calling the project DStat (unless someone can come up with a better name). It will hopefully become a fully fledged statistics library for performing operations on multiple types of distributions of data. As of now it only has a few functions, but feel free to take a look at that and the other projects over at my GitHub page. I try to make progress whenever I find free time to do a little extra work. Feel free to contribute too! Everything I do I release as open source.

I eventually would like to be able to take some data you might find from your own Google Data Archive and within a few minutes (using DStat of course!) come up with some neat conclusions based on your own search habits or other usage statistics. Of course it might be some time before that's possible I hope that in time you will be able to find that kind of functionality with it.

item.title: Data....Science?
item.description:
So, I'll have to break it to you now I guess. If you couldn't already tell from the title of this blog I'm really into the whole 'big data' thing. I think data science is a really cool and interesting field that's starting to emerge. Universities are offering new courses on data science and some are even starting degree programs.

This past semester I took a Byrne Seminar called Data: What is it Good for? (Absolutely Something) It was taught by two ECE faculty here at Rutgers. I'll link to their pages at the end.

The class really opened up my eyes to this whole whole new prospect of data and put it in this different light. We don't realize the potential that all these numbers have. They all tell part of a huge story, and the data tells different stories too! The possibilities are really almost endless.

I'm excited to be in the position I am in now to see how the field evolves over the next 5-10 years and what advances we make.

I'm also really interested in machine learning and the solutions it proposes to solving some problems.

Here's an interesting video I found over at reddit.com/r/machinelearning on teaching computers how to automatically caption digital photographs. I found it really interesting.


Links to my professor's pages. I think they have some really interesting research.

Anand Sarwate

Waheed Bajwa

item.title: Creation
item.description:
Being the first post here I feel compelled to at least introduce myself to anyone who decides to read my blog.

My name is Zac Blanco. I'm currently an undergraduate studying Electrical and Computer Engineering at Rutgers University. I hope to also double major with computer science, and eventually continue on to graduate school. My expected graduation date is May of 2018

I wanted to start a blog to share my thoughts and ideas about any of my work, projects, and other interests. Most topics here will converge on ideas in computer science theory, programming, and technology.

Enjoy!
